thread.title: Portraits of all kinds at the Frye Art Museum
thread.title_full: Portraits of all kinds at the Frye Art Museum | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: Portraits of all kinds at the Frye Art Museum
text:
With all the attention focused on the Leo Saul Berk installation at the Frye Art Museum — and rightfully so, given the nature of it — visitors might have missed two other worthy Frye exhibits that are nearing the end of their run: “Andy Warhol: 12 Screen Tests,” departing Sept. 13, and “American Portraits,” ending Aug. 30. Media in both shows aim to show an individual’s image, of course, but they also raise the question: How does the viewer come to understand a subject? Is a “living portrait” of Bob Dylan (shown here, “Andy Warhol, Screen Test: Bob Dylan [ST83],” 1966) any more illuminating than the somber 1895 oil of “The Stoker,” by Robert Henri (also shown here) — a prime example of late-20th-century efforts to depict “real life”? The Frye is open 11 a.m.-5 p.m. Tuesdays-Sundays, 11 a.m.-7 p.m. Thursdays, 704 Terry Ave., Seattle; free (206-622-9250 or fryemuseum.org ).
Seattle Times staff
